commit_message:
Dell SC driver honoring folder name after volume creation.

The Dell SC driver was not honoring the volume folder name
after creation.  This has been changed so that find_volume
now checks the dell_sc_volume_folder for the requested volume
before doing a general search of the storage center.  In
either case if more than one volume is returned (two in
the dell_sc_volume_folder or two outside of that folder) then
an exception is thrown.

Also the dell_sc_volume_folder, dell_sc_server_folder and
dell_sc_ssn variables are no longer being passed arond.  They
are saved as part of the backend API object.

Tests have been updated.

Change-Id: I962ea3ed262d21deff65cdc8476939aab6ba07e2
Closes-Bug: #1449290

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/24/186224/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>A persistent volume can only be accessed by a single configured instance, it cannot be configured for multiple instances to access the persistent volume. This type of configuration to allow for multiple instances accessing the persistent volume requires a traditional network file system like NFS, or CIFS, or a cluster file system such as GlusterFS. These systems can be built within an OpenStack cluster, or provisioned outside of it, but OpenStack software does not provide these features.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>A persistent volume is created by a user, and its size is limited only by a user's quota and availability limits. Upon initial creation, a volume is a raw block device without a partition table or a file system. To partition or format a volume, you must attach it to an instance. Once it is attached, it can be used the same way as an external hard disk drive. A single volume can be attached to one instance at a time, though you can detach and reattach it to other instances as many times as required.</para>

commit_message:
Fix Flavor Detail tbl in legacy Launch Instance

This patch fixes the misaligned rows of the Flavour Details table, on
the first tab of the legacy Launch Instance workflow.

Patch also changes the markup for the Networks tab, which relied on CSS
that this patch removes.

Change-Id: Ie2fcedb5a7a7f5b3d9ffffd4f245f7ec5ff5470d
Closes-Bug: 1443322

commit_message:
Fix TemplateDoesNotExist at manage/unmanage volumes

manage/unmanage template includes wrong templates:

project/volumes/volumes/_unmanage_volume.html
project/volumes/volumes/_manage_volume.html

it should be admin/volumes/... instead of project/volumes/...

Change-Id: Ic1b16077630b39b8a72e773c562de2c65a5a11c3
Closes-Bug: #1459625
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/91/186391/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Auto-delete queues were deleted on RabbitMQ failover
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-26 08:12:04.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_rabbit.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/840774c6b73234f4935f8ed218002b7fa029f147', 'message': "Auto-delete queues were deleted on RabbitMQ failover

When RPC client starts listening to reply queue and got disconnected from RabbitMQ,
reply queue got deleted because it was marked as auto-delete and no more consumers
were present.

This fix replaces auto-delete with queue 1H expiration. So clients have
up to an hour to reconnect to RaqbbitMQ prior to server's reply gets lost

Adopted from Ic1a20c309ff90618f715f4034847e6e159c486e8
Co-Authored-By: Stan Lagun<slagun@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I9119ee7fa798918811044625271140fabd812651
Closes-Bug: #1349301
"}]
commit_message:
Auto-delete queues were deleted on RabbitMQ failover

When RPC client starts listening to reply queue and got disconnected from RabbitMQ,
reply queue got deleted because it was marked as auto-delete and no more consumers
were present.

This fix replaces auto-delete with queue 1H expiration. So clients have
up to an hour to reconnect to RaqbbitMQ prior to server's reply gets lost

Adopted from Ic1a20c309ff90618f715f4034847e6e159c486e8
Co-Authored-By: Stan Lagun<slagun@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I9119ee7fa798918811044625271140fabd812651
Closes-Bug: #1349301
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/25/185525/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if self.auto_delete and not self.queue_arguments.get('x-expires'): self.queue_arguments['x-expires'] = 60 * 60 * 1000 # 1 hour auto_delete = False else: auto_delete = self.auto_delete auto_delete=auto_delete,

commit_message:
Refactor/reduce shared 'ensure(task/retry)' code

These methods are nearly identical so we should refactor
them to use the same code for sanity and understanding
purposes.

Change-Id: Ibaf270bd451b6d02d7782901bc2327afe04d3847
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/29/170229/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not isinstance(atom, (task.BaseTask, retry.Retry)): raise TypeError("Unknown atom '%s' (%s) requested to ensure" if isinstance(atom, (task.BaseTask)): kind = 'task' storage_cls = logbook.TaskDetail else: kind = 'retry' storage_cls = logbook.RetryDetail atom_name = atom.name atom_version = misc.get_version_string(atom) result_mapping = atom.save_as atom_id = self._ensure_atom(kind, storage_cls, atom_name, atom_version, result_mapping) return atom_id def _ensure_atom(self, kind, storage_cls, atom_name, atom_version, result_mapping): """Ensures there is a atomdetail that corresponds to the given atom. If atom does not exist, adds a record for it. Added atom will have PENDING state. Sets result mapping for the atom from result_mapping Returns uuid for the atomdetails corresponding to the atom with if not atom_name: raise ValueError("%s name must be non-empty" % (kind.title())) atom_id = self._atom_name_to_uuid[atom_name] except KeyError: atom_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() self._create_atom_detail(storage_cls, atom_name, atom_id, atom_version) else: ad = self._flowdetail.find(atom_id) if not isinstance(ad, storage_cls): "Atom detail '%s' already exists in flow" " detail '%s'" % (atom_name, self._flowdetail.name)) self._set_result_mapping(atom_name, result_mapping) return atom_id def _create_atom_detail(self, storage_cls, name, uuid, task_version=None): ad = storage_cls(name, uuid)
deleted_lines: self._ensure_matchers = [ ((task.BaseTask,), self._ensure_task), ((retry.Retry,), self._ensure_retry), ] functor = misc.match_type_handler(atom, self._ensure_matchers) if not functor: raise TypeError("Unknown item '%s' (%s) requested to ensure" return functor(atom.name, misc.get_version_string(atom), atom.save_as) def _ensure_task(self, task_name, task_version, result_mapping): """Ensures there is a taskdetail that corresponds to the task info. If task does not exist, adds a record for it. Added task will have PENDING state. Sets result mapping for the task from result_mapping Returns uuid for the task details corresponding to the task with if not task_name: raise ValueError("Task name must be non-empty") task_id = self._atom_name_to_uuid[task_name] except KeyError: task_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() self._create_atom_detail(logbook.TaskDetail, task_name, task_id, task_version) else: ad = self._flowdetail.find(task_id) if not isinstance(ad, logbook.TaskDetail): "Atom detail %s already exists in flow detail %s." % (task_name, self._flowdetail.name)) self._set_result_mapping(task_name, result_mapping) return task_id def _ensure_retry(self, retry_name, retry_version, result_mapping): """Ensures there is a retrydetail that corresponds to the retry info. If retry does not exist, adds a record for it. Added retry will have PENDING state. Sets result mapping for the retry from result_mapping argument. Initializes retry result as an empty collections of results and failures history. Returns uuid for the retry details corresponding to the retry with given name. """ if not retry_name: raise ValueError("Retry name must be non-empty") with self._lock.write_lock(): try: retry_id = self._atom_name_to_uuid[retry_name] except KeyError: retry_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() self._create_atom_detail(logbook.RetryDetail, retry_name, retry_id, retry_version) else: ad = self._flowdetail.find(retry_id) if not isinstance(ad, logbook.RetryDetail): raise exceptions.Duplicate( "Atom detail %s already exists in flow detail %s." % (retry_name, self._flowdetail.name)) self._set_result_mapping(retry_name, result_mapping) return retry_id def _create_atom_detail(self, _detail_cls, name, uuid, task_version=None): ad = _detail_cls(name, uuid)

commit_message:
Fix the wrong check when boot from volume

Now,when create a server booting from volume.It will
raise an unexpcted 'FlavorDiskTooSmall' error in some
case.

For example,use 1G flavor and a 2G bootable volume of
which the image is small than 1G.The error would be
occured.

Change-Id: If4d04340a82ec98de6f44c485dd8d683284d0f06
Closes-bug: #1457517
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/22/185322/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Change-Id: I7f7e6600f03c67376ba310ab231b2e33cd7528db
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure empty paths raise a value error

Empty paths should not be allowed to be set or
fetched or normalized so check for those and raise
an error when one is encountered.

Also add some basic test conditions that ensure
the normpath method raises when it should.

Change-Id: I7f7e6600f03c67376ba310ab231b2e33cd7528db
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/57/182157/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_bad_norms(self): fs = impl_memory.FakeFilesystem() self.assertRaises(ValueError, fs.normpath, '') self.assertRaises(ValueError, fs.normpath, 'abc/c') self.assertRaises(ValueError, fs.normpath, '../c')

commit_message:
Small refactoring of 'merge_uri' utility function

Perform some small adjustments/cleanups and add some
unit tests to ensure this function keeps operating as
expected.

Change-Id: I496bd6844072f57624de31fc7ddb0362f163cc53
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/91/179491/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def merge_uri(uri, conf, include_hostname=True, include_username=True, include_password=True): the given configuration if requested to (it does **not** overwrite existing configuration keys if they already exist) and returns the adjusted configuration. specials = [] if include_username: specials.append(('username', uri.username)) if include_password: specials.append(('password', uri.password)) if include_hostname: if hostname: if uri.port is not None: hostname += ":%s" % (uri.port) specials.append(('hostname', hostname)) for (k, v) in specials: if v: conf.setdefault(k, v)
deleted_lines: def merge_uri(uri, conf): the given configuration (it does not overwrite the configuration keys if they already exist) and returns the adjusted configuration. for (k, v) in [('username', uri.username), ('password', uri.password)]: if not v: continue conf.setdefault(k, v) if uri.hostname: if uri.port is not None: hostname += ":%s" % (uri.port) conf.setdefault('hostname', hostname)

commit_message:
Start adding rejection policy prototype to executors (WIP)

It is often desirable to have an executor do something
else then queue up work when its workers are at capacity.

To start to support this we need to start defining and
adding support to the existing executors so that they accept
and respect a provided policy.

Experiment for http://bugs.python.org/issue22737

Change-Id: Ieac2f8c002a96f98cf93fbd3e92afbd4b13702e1

commit_message:
Use states.check_task/retry_transition in action(s)

Be more strict about our task and retry transition(s) and
call into the state transition checking function(s) to ensure
that we continue making valid transition(s) or die.

Change-Id: Ib016e787a9382d06d4a7c15298bbcaa9a3f80368

commit_message:
Switch from MySQL-python to PyMySQL

As discussed in the Liberty Design Summit "Moving apps to Python 3"
cross-project workshop, the way forward in the near future is to
switch to the pure-python PyMySQL library as a default.

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/liberty-cross-project-python3

Change-Id: I55ec1908f330e8f106b4e4f8e2435b5135b22e85

commit_message:
Document how to use network isolation/static IPs

This patch adds a file documenting the use of isolated networks with static
IP addresses. This optional functionality allows the use of static IP addresses
on networks based on function: Internal API, tenant, storage, storage management,
and external/public API.

Change-Id: I185c6d87cb4e84d7c58ac279b8e6609d876c82c9
Co-Authored-By: dprince@redhat.com
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/54/186954/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: TripleO Overcloud Network Isolation =================================== Intro ----- This document outlines how to deploy a TripleO overcloud with split out (isolated) physical networks for various types of traffic. Using this approach it is possible to host traffic for specific types of network traffic (tenants, storage, cluster managment, etc.) in isolated networks. This is in contrast to the TripleO default network topology which hosts all traffic on the same flat 'ctlplane' network used for provisioning, and tenant traffic runs in a GRE or VXLAN tunnel on the same physical network. IP address management is done with Neutron. In this document we describe how to modify the tripleo-heat-templates to create networks, and assign static IP addresses on multiple network interfaces to each machine deployed to host the Overcloud. Creating Extra Physical Networks -------------------------------- A physical network is created on the undercloud Neutron for each isolated network you wish to create. This is accomplished by using the Heat OS::Neutron::Net resource within tripleo-heat-templates. By default, each TripleO::Network resource is defined by the ``network/noop.yaml`` file, which does not create a network and instead always points to the Undercloud 'ctlplane' network (the provisioning network). The default values in the resource registry may be overriden in an environment file to enable the networks. To enable extra networks to be created, each network definition file needs to be referenced in the environment file. Example:: resource_registry: # TripleO network architecture OS::TripleO::Network: network/networks.yaml OS::TripleO::Network::External: network/external.yaml OS::TripleO::Network::InternalApi: network/internal_api.yaml OS::TripleO::Network::Storage: network/storage.yaml OS::TripleO::Network::StorageMgmt: network/storage_mgmt.yaml OS::TripleO::Network::Tenant: network/tenant.yaml .. note:: It should be noted that creation of these split out networks via the tripleo-heat-templates is optional. It is entirely possible to use os-cloud-config's setup-neutron script to do the same thing. The tripleo-heat-template approach is beneficial in that it allows you to customize the networks using environment files with template parameters. Customizing Network CIDR ------------------------ Each network template within the tripleo-heat-templates ``network`` directory contains parameters that allow you to customize how it is created. One of the most common changes would be to use a custom network CIDR for each network. Although default ranges have been specified for each network type these are editable by setting a parameter value in an environment file. Example:: parameter_defaults: ExternalNetCidr: 10.0.0.0/24 InternalApiNetCidr: 172.17.0.0/24 StorageNetCidr: 172.18.0.0/24 StorageNetCidr: 172.19.0.0/24 TenantNetCidr: 172.16.0.0/24 Network Assignments by Role --------------------------- Each flavor of OpenStack servers has a set of networks that are associated with that flavor. The Controller nodes need to connect to every network, but other flavors only need to connect to a subset of the networks. This is defined in the role definition file, e.g. ``controller-puppet.yaml``. Controller: External, Internal API, Storage, Storage Mgmt, Tenant Compute: Internal API, Storage, Tenant Object Storage: Internal API, Storage, Storage Mgmt Block Storage: Internal API, Storage, Storage Mgmt Ceph Storage: Internal API, Storage, Storage Mgmt Assinging OpenStack Services to Isolated Networks ------------------------------------------------- Each OpenStack service is assigned to a network in the resource registry. The service will be bound to the host IP within the named network on each host. A service can be assigned to an alternate network by overriding the service to network map in an environment file. Example:: parameter_defaults: ServiceNetMap: NeutronLocalIp: tenant CeilometerApiNetwork: internal_api MongoDbNetwork: internal_api CinderApiNetwork: internal_api CinderIscsiNetwork: storage GlanceApiNetwork: storage GlanceRegistryNetwork: internal_api .. note:: Although the OpenStack services are divided among these 5 named networks, the number of actual physical networks may differ. For instance, if a given deployment had no separate storage network, the tenant network could be used for both VM connectivity and storage. ServiceNetMap determines which networks are used for which services. Assigning Ports to Each Machine ------------------------------- Each server will have a set of ports created for it, one on each network where the server is attached. Each port has an associated IP address, and the IP addresses are passed on for use by Puppet and os-net-config. The network interfaces are configured with the IPs by os-net-config, and Puppet configures the OpenStack services to bind to the IPs. The mapping of the ports is done in the files in the ``network/ports`` subdirectory in the tripleo-heat-templates. The following example maps the IP address associated with a port to a parameter (ip_subnet) which is used to write out the os-net-config configuration files and the Puppet hieradata. Example:: heat_template_version: 2015-04-30 description: > Creates a port on the storage network. parameters: StorageNetName: description: Name of the storage neutron network default: storage type: string ControlPlaneIP: # Here for compatability with noop.yaml description: IP address on the control plane type: string resources: StoragePort: type: OS::Neutron::Port properties: network: {get_param: StorageNetName} replacement_policy: AUTO outputs: ip_address: description: storage network IP value: {get_attr: [StoragePort, fixed_ips, 0, ip_address]} ip_subnet: # FIXME: this assumes a 2 digit subnet CIDR (need more heat functions?) description: IP/Subnet CIDR for the storage network IP value: list_join: - '' - - {get_attr: [StoragePort, fixed_ips, 0, ip_address]} - '/' - {get_attr: [StoragePort, subnets, 0, cidr, -2]} - {get_attr: [StoragePort, subnets, 0, cidr, -1]} Configuring Assigned Ports with Custom os-net-config Templates -------------------------------------------------------------- The following example configures additional tenant and storage networks alongside of the default ctlplane network which is used for provisioning and Heat API updates. Example:: heat_template_version: 2014-10-16 description: > Software Config to drive os-net-config for a compute node. parameters: ExternalIpSubnet: description: an ip address on the external network type: string InternalApiIpSubnet: description: an ip address on the internal API network type: string StorageIpSubnet: description: an ip address on the storage network type: string StorageMgmtIpSubnet: description: an ip address on the storage management network type: string TenantIpSubnet: description: an ip address on the tenant network type: string resources: OsNetConfigImpl: type: OS::Heat::StructuredConfig properties: group: os-apply-config config: os_net_config: network_config: - type: interface name: nic1 # Undercloud 'ctlplane' provisioning net use_dhcp: true - type: interface name: nic2 use_dhcp: false addresses: - ip_netmask: {get_param: InternalApiIpSubnet} - type: interface name: nic3 use_dhcp: false addresses: - ip_netmask: {get_param: TenantIpSubnet} - type: interface name: nic4 use_dhcp: false addresses: - ip_netmask: {get_param: StorageIpSubnet}

commit_message:
Create iSCSI lio portals with right IPs and port

Currently lioadm helper creates portals with fixed IP addresses 0.0.0.0
and ::0 and also uses fixed standard port 3260 instead of using store
configuration (iscsi_ip_address, iscsi_secondary_ip_addresses,
iscsi_port) from the configuration as it should.

This could lead to problems if a different port was defined in the
configuration as the target would be available only on 3260 and other
services would look for it at configured port.

With this fix we now create the right portals with the right port.

Since now we pass list of ips and port to helpers cxt helper has also
been updated to use these parameters instead of going directly to the
configuration.

Change-Id: I77e8865b1f015a9fa155f2b4552a5d9c27f5e122
Closes-Bug: #1425875

subject: Expand the vote range for governance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-29 22:28:03.000000000', 'files': ['gerrit/acls/openstack/governance.config'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/62b46db2179b3e78bf15b6a3c0289b9cbb7a7720', 'message': 'Expand the vote range for governance

The voting configuration for governance produces a red-x and
green-check for +/-1 code reviews now, which is confusing to people
since they normally associate those icons with +/-2 votes.  This
change expands the vote range to include +/-2 but gives no one
permission to vote at those levels.  This should cause Code-Review
votes to appear as +/-1, while the NoOp function continues to
mean that +2 votes are not necessary.

Change-Id: I31adfe3c847d181809825e1030e8c165e67ae9aa
'}]
commit_message:
Expand the vote range for governance

The voting configuration for governance produces a red-x and
green-check for +/-1 code reviews now, which is confusing to people
since they normally associate those icons with +/-2 votes.  This
change expands the vote range to include +/-2 but gives no one
permission to vote at those levels.  This should cause Code-Review
votes to appear as +/-1, while the NoOp function continues to
mean that +2 votes are not necessary.

Change-Id: I31adfe3c847d181809825e1030e8c165e67ae9aa

commit_message:
Simplify the check for whether a metric matches

The old way was more efficient if there were few dimensions on
the metric and lots of Alarm Definitions with different
dimension sets for a given tenant id and metric name, but that
is probably unlikely. The more common case will be one or two
alarm definitions per tenant id and metric name and more
dimensions on the metric. The new algorithm is faster for that
case since it doesn't create every possible combinations of
dimensions like the old algorithm

Change-Id: I183570d52c61f0a2932cf37c5c659a6c529b4bbb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-thresh refs/changes/73/184673/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Hyper-V: Fixes cold migration / resize issue
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-11 14:33:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d0acbeb8280e0688f3f5e9116fb5eb79919799ee', 'message': "Hyper-V: Fixes cold migration / resize issue

Commit https://review.openstack.org/#/c/162999/ changed where the Hyper-V
VM configuration files are stored. The files are being stored in the same
folder as the instance. Performing a cold resize / migration will cause a
os.rename call on the instance's folder, which fails as long as there are
configuration files used by Hyper-V in that folder, thus resulting in a
failed migration and the instance ending up in ERROR state.

Hyper-V configuration files are stored in a subfolder of the instance's
folder (e.g.: C:\OpenStack\Instances\instance-000000b6\Virtual Machines).

This commit makes sure that Hyper-V configuration files are not being
moved during migration by skipping subfolders in the instance's folder.

Change-Id: I4874eed7d284fab241e4371e550a88270ca156f1
Closes-Bug: #1453835

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Fixes cold migration / resize issue

Commit 3e42c7ae3f7a9353834c8c9c4dc79ee39dd0783b changed where the Hyper-V
VM configuration files are stored. The files are being stored in the same
folder as the instance. Performing a cold resize / migration will cause a
os.rename call on the instance's folder, which fails as long as there are
configuration files used by Hyper-V in that folder, thus resulting in a
failed migration and the instance ending up in ERROR state.

Hyper-V configuration files are stored in a subfolder of the instance's
folder (e.g.: C:\OpenStack\Instances\instance-000000b6\Virtual Machines).

This commit makes sure that Hyper-V configuration files are not being
moved during migration by skipping subfolders in the instance's folder.

Change-Id: I4874eed7d284fab241e4371e550a88270ca156f1
Closes-Bug: #1453835

commit_message:
attach tags to core resources

The spec proposes a new table to allow tagging of
core resources.

Change-Id: I798132acc8aed922304357f4934e58317dbadcf7
APIImpact
Blueprint: core-resource-tags
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/69/134069/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================= Allow association of meta data for core resources ================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/core-resource-metadata This blueprint proposes to add a new attribute to the core resources - networks, subnets and ports. The attribute, metadata, is intended to save meta-data for the resource as per the providers requirements. Problem Description =================== Currently the core resources do not have any associated metadata but there are many instances where the orchestration layer could use the information to make intelligent decision. The metadata attribute can have any value that is deemed necessary to operate the network. E.g. an operator may want to access networks with certain properties which can be encoded in the metadata field. It is proposed below that a metadata attribute is added to the core resources which contains the serialized JSON data. The serialized JSON data may only contain simple key-value pairs and not an arbirarily complex data structure. The meta-data is interpreted by users and possibly orchestration layer and not by the plugins. It is opaque to the plugins (we need to think about how to make it inaccessible to plugin). Proposed Change =============== We propose that the following is updated: * neutron/api/v2/attributes.py modify NETWORKS, SUBNETS and PORTS to include the 'metadata' attribute. * migration add an alembic migration script to populate the field with default (empty value) * neutronclient update client to allow creating and updating the values in metadata. It should accept key-value pairs which will be serialized to json. Data Model Impact ----------------- This is going to require updating the schema for networks, subnets and ports. An alembic migration script will populate the new field with a default value. This is an optional attribute. REST API Impact --------------- No new APIs are needed. The following attribute is added to the networks, subnets and ports table. So the APIs for the resources will be impacted to accommodate the changes in attribute map. +----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+------------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |Validation/ |Description | |Name | | |Value |Conversion | | +==========+=======+=========+=========+============+==================+ |metadata |string |RW, all |'' |N/A |operator-specific | | | | | | |meta-data | +----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+------------------+ * Example use case including typical API samples for both data supplied by the caller and the response Simple use-case - all hypervisors are plugged into multiple networks. Operator needs to boot a VM in a specific network. By creating metadata for networks the orchestration is simplified as well as standardized. In this case, let us assume the operator has a network that higher throughput (perhaps offered to those paying higher costs) and one with lower throughput. If the operator is able to store some metadata for the resources like networks it is simple to select one for a given VM. There could be other constraints like SLA and underlying infrastruture reliability. E.g. the meta-data for network could be " { 'speed': '10G', 'customer_type': 'B' }". Security Impact --------------- N/A Notifications Impact -------------------- N/A Other End User Impact --------------------- It will introduce a new attribute that can be specified when creating a core resource, or modifying one. $> neutron create-network Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- The deployer could now use these additional attributes to make decisions about VM-placement, network-selection, etc. during orchestration and take appropriate actions. If attributes are not used there is no impact. Developer Impact ---------------- None Community Impact ---------------- This was discussed in Atlanta+Paris in pod area but there was no design session specifically for this. In general, there is a need to be able to associate a resource with certain operator attributes and there seems to be general requirement in community for something like this. Alternatives ------------ Other ways to solve the problem is to extend the attributes of the resources and have a separate table to store the metadata. However, this is something that a lot of operators are doing and it should not be required to write an extension for such a basic functionality. Having it in the core also avoids duplcation. Without maintaining the data along with the resource, another alternative is to maintain another table and associate the resource-type and its uuid with the attributes desired. But again, this maybe a lot of duplictaion for several operators who need this. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: vbannai Other contributors: manishatyhoo, sudhi-vm, shraddha-pandhe Work Items ---------- update model, write unit-tests, modify neutron-client. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- None - API tests mentioned below should cover the testing. Functional Tests ---------------- There is no specific functional test as this blueprint is only suggesting additional attribute that will be used by orchestration logic outside of neutron. API Tests --------- unit tests will be modified to test each of the resourse to make sure proper validation is done. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ In the description on network, subnet and port creation we should add that a metadata can supplied at the time of creation and that it can be modified by the operators. http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/cli_networks.html http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/cli_subnetworks.html http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/cli_ports.html Developer Documentation ----------------------- The API should be updated to identify the new attribute for the core resources - http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-networking-v2.html References ========== None

commit_message:
server-group-list support 'all_projects' parameter

Supporting 'all_projects' in server-group-list so that
admin users can list other tenant's server groups.

Change-Id: Ie50288464ebc6585590a1a74efa8804584771ebc
Closes-Bug: #1454523

commit_message:
Sort _get_new/deleted_set_ips responses in unittests

This fixes the test_set_members_adding/deleting_less_than_5 unit test
that breaks with a randomized PYTHONHASHSEED (see the bug report).

The test assumed that the _get_new/deleted_set_ips from
neutron.agent.linux.ipset_manager return elements in a particular order.
Found with PYTHONHASHSEED=1.

The fix refactors the test case to force sorted responses from
_get_new/deleted_set_ips during unittests.

Partial-bug: #1348818

Note: There are several other unrelated unit tests that also break with
a randomized PYTHONHASHSEED, but they are not addressed here. They will
be addressed in separate patches.

Change-Id: I8408365825ec1e97a83c2181f38ec1f9468df91e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/33/185633/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: original_get_new_set_ips = self.ipset._get_new_set_ips original_get_deleted_set_ips = self.ipset._get_deleted_set_ips def sorted_get_new_set_ips(set_name, expected_ips): unsorted = original_get_new_set_ips(set_name, expected_ips) return sorted(unsorted, reverse=True) def sorted_get_deleted_set_ips(set_name, expected_ips): unsorted = original_get_deleted_set_ips(set_name, expected_ips) return sorted(unsorted, reverse=True) mock.patch.object(self.ipset, '_get_new_set_ips', side_effect=sorted_get_new_set_ips).start() mock.patch.object(self.ipset, '_get_deleted_set_ips', side_effect=sorted_get_deleted_set_ips).start() self.expect_del(reversed(FAKE_IPS[3:]))

commit_message:
Allow to remove second _send_reply() call

Added a new configuration option `send_single_reply` which allows to
send a single AMQP reply instead of two. This will reduce amount of RPC
calls and increase transport productivity.

The new behaviour is not compatible with the old logic, so isn't
backward compatible and disabled by default.

DocImpact
A new configuration option added.

Blueprint: remove-double-reply

Change-Id: Idab118b22163e734aca010f325cddfaec26bfa0f

deleted_lines: def _send_reply(self, conn, reply=None, failure=None, ending=False, log_failure=True): if ending: msg['ending'] = True self._send_reply(conn, ending=True) ending = False elif data.get('ending', False): ending = True return result, ending # NOTE(sileht): for each msg_id we receive two amqp message # first one with the payload, a second one to ensure the other # have finish to send the payload final_reply = None ending = False while not ending: timeout = timer.check_return(self._raise_timeout_exception, msg_id) try: message = self.waiters.get(msg_id, timeout=timeout) except moves.queue.Empty: self._raise_timeout_exception(msg_id) reply, ending = self._process_reply(message) if not ending: final_reply = reply return final_reply

commit_message:
Don't assume project IDs are UUID format

Since Keystone has the ability to be deployed with an LDAP backend, we can't
guarantee that project IDs will always be UUID formatted. That change makes it
so that we attempt to convert project IDs to bytes before packing and if we
fail, pass the original project ID into the payload at the expense of a
slightly longer payload.

Change-Id: Id81ed23879ee7a9adeb50454ef0cb7acd13f1a0a
Related-Bug: 1459382
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/93/186393/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_project_scoped_payload_with_non_uuid_project_id(self): exp_user_id = uuid.uuid4().hex exp_methods = ['password'] exp_project_id = 'someNonUuidProjectId' exp_expires_at = timeutils.isotime(timeutils.utcnow()) exp_audit_ids = [provider.random_urlsafe_str()] payload = token_formatters.ProjectScopedPayload.assemble( exp_user_id, exp_methods, exp_project_id, exp_expires_at, exp_audit_ids) (user_id, methods, project_id, expires_at, audit_ids) = ( token_formatters.ProjectScopedPayload.disassemble(payload)) self.assertEqual(exp_user_id, user_id) self.assertEqual(exp_methods, methods) self.assertEqual(exp_project_id, project_id) self.assertEqual(exp_expires_at, expires_at) self.assertEqual(exp_audit_ids, audit_ids) def test_trust_scoped_payload_with_non_uuid_project_id(self): exp_user_id = uuid.uuid4().hex exp_methods = ['password'] exp_project_id = 'someNonUuidProjectId' exp_expires_at = timeutils.isotime(timeutils.utcnow()) exp_audit_ids = [provider.random_urlsafe_str()] exp_trust_id = uuid.uuid4().hex payload = token_formatters.TrustScopedPayload.assemble( exp_user_id, exp_methods, exp_project_id, exp_expires_at, exp_audit_ids, exp_trust_id) (user_id, methods, project_id, expires_at, audit_ids, trust_id) = ( token_formatters.TrustScopedPayload.disassemble(payload)) self.assertEqual(exp_user_id, user_id) self.assertEqual(exp_methods, methods) self.assertEqual(exp_project_id, project_id) self.assertEqual(exp_expires_at, expires_at) self.assertEqual(exp_audit_ids, audit_ids) self.assertEqual(exp_trust_id, trust_id)

commit_message:
Don't assume group IDs are UUID format

When using the Fernet token provider to build a federated payload, we can't
assume that the group ID will always be a UUID format that we can convert to
bytes. This change makes the Fernet code smart enough to pass the original
group ID in the payload if it can't convert it to bytes.

Change-Id: I6d00902eb461c22aafd9cb5ca706b05bedefd37d
Related-Bug: 1459382
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/92/186392/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_federated_payload_with_non_uuid_ids(self): exp_user_id = 'someNonUuidUserId' exp_methods = ['password'] exp_expires_at = timeutils.isotime(timeutils.utcnow()) exp_audit_ids = [provider.random_urlsafe_str()] exp_federated_info = {'group_ids': [{'id': 'someNonUuidGroupId'}], 'idp_id': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'protocol_id': uuid.uuid4().hex} payload = token_formatters.FederatedPayload.assemble( exp_user_id, exp_methods, exp_expires_at, exp_audit_ids, exp_federated_info) (user_id, methods, expires_at, audit_ids, federated_info) = ( token_formatters.FederatedPayload.disassemble(payload)) self.assertEqual(exp_user_id, user_id) self.assertEqual(exp_methods, methods) self.assertEqual(exp_expires_at, expires_at) self.assertEqual(exp_audit_ids, audit_ids) self.assertEqual(exp_federated_info['group_ids'][0]['id'], federated_info['group_ids'][0]['id']) self.assertEqual(exp_federated_info['idp_id'], federated_info['idp_id']) self.assertEqual(exp_federated_info['protocol_id'], federated_info['protocol_id'])

Old ipset/kernel versions cannot properly use ipset in namespaces.
While we don't use ipset in namespaces in production code, we do

patch.

Change-Id: I3f3d108df14f1583f558643c555a17ed3fd6ca5a

Old ipset/kernel versions cannot properly use ipset in namespaces.
While we don't use ipset in namespaces in production code, we do
during functional testing. This patch adds a sanity check while will
be used to determine if the ipset tests should be run in a future
patch.

The check properly succeeds or fails and cleans up all resources
in both cases.

The check properly succeeds or fails and cleans up all resources
in both cases.

Related-Bug: #1459855
Change-Id: I3f3d108df14f1583f558643c555a17ed3fd6ca5a
"}]
commit_message:
Add sanity test for ipset in a namespace

Old ipset/kernel versions cannot properly use ipset in namespaces.
While we don't use ipset in namespaces in production code, we do
during functional testing. This patch adds a sanity check while will
be used to determine if the ipset tests should be run in a future
patch.

The sanity check was run on both a new and old kernel/ipset.
The check properly succeeds or fails and cleans up all resources
in both cases.

Related-Bug: #1459855
Change-Id: I3f3d108df14f1583f558643c555a17ed3fd6ca5a

Please upgrade' 'your kernel and ipset versions.')) return result BoolOptCallback('ipset', check_ipset_in_namespace, help=_('Check if ipset can be used in a namespace')), if cfg.CONF.SECURITYGROUP.enable_ipset: cfg.CONF.set_override('ipset', True)

subject: Expand the vote range for infra-specs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-29 22:25:30.000000000', 'files': ['gerrit/acls/openstack-infra/infra-specs.config'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/862f5f741cfd692b04d37a8c5b6f37cb4eac4fd4', 'message': 'Expand the vote range for infra-specs

The voting configuration for infra-specs produces a red-x and
green-check for +/-1 code reviews now, which is confusing to people
since they normally associate those icons with +/-2 votes.  This
change expands the vote range to include +/-2 but gives no one
permission to vote at those levels.  This should cause Code-Review
votes to appear as +/-1, while the NoOp function continues to
mean that +2 votes are not necessary.

Also extend the Council-Vote to +2, but similarly give no permissions
to use it so that council votes will appear as +1, -1, or red-x in
the case of a -2 veto (the -1/green-check dichotomy would also
seem weird for similar reasons).

Change-Id: I042e6168334fb11291edbaed97b3ae2424218166
'}]
commit_message:
Expand the vote range for infra-specs

The voting configuration for infra-specs produces a red-x and
green-check for +/-1 code reviews now, which is confusing to people
since they normally associate those icons with +/-2 votes.  This
change expands the vote range to include +/-2 but gives no one
permission to vote at those levels.  This should cause Code-Review
votes to appear as +/-1, while the NoOp function continues to
mean that +2 votes are not necessary.

Also extend the Council-Vote to +2, but similarly give no permissions
to use it so that council votes will appear as +1, -1, or red-x in
the case of a -2 veto (the -1/green-check dichotomy would also
seem weird for similar reasons).

Change-Id: I042e6168334fb11291edbaed97b3ae2424218166

commit_message:
go: replace ghetto getpwnam with os/user

Parsing /etc/passwd was always goofy, but some stuff that came up when
googling "golang getpwnam" led me to believe this functionality just
didn't exist in the go standard library.

Then I ran across os/user a few days ago, which is exactly what's needed.

Change-Id: I937f0a1397c70dc3f7b5b77d939deb10d6c7c480
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/35/183635/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
"fmt" "os/user" "strconv" func TestUidFromConf(t *testing.T) { usr, err := user.Current() assert.Nil(t, err) tempFile, err := ioutil.TempFile("", "INI") assert.Nil(t, err) defer os.RemoveAll(tempFile.Name()) defer tempFile.Close() fmt.Fprintf(tempFile, "[DEFAULT]
user=%s
", usr.Username) currentUid, err := strconv.ParseUint(usr.Uid, 10, 32) assert.Nil(t, err) currentGid, err := strconv.ParseUint(usr.Gid, 10, 32) assert.Nil(t, err) uid, gid, err := UidFromConf(tempFile.Name()) assert.Nil(t, err) assert.Equal(t, currentUid, uid) assert.Equal(t, currentGid, gid) } func TestUidFromConfFailure(t *testing.T) { tempFile, err := ioutil.TempFile("", "INI") assert.Nil(t, err) defer os.RemoveAll(tempFile.Name()) defer tempFile.Close() fmt.Fprintf(tempFile, "[DEFAULT]
user=SomeUserWhoShouldntExist
") _, _, err = UidFromConf(tempFile.Name()) assert.NotNil(t, err) }

commit_message:
Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for service_get_by_host*

This patches remove the hard-code permission checks for db call
service_get_by_host_and_topic and service_get_all_by_host_and_binary.

There are elevated contexts in the code used to call those methods which
aren't removed in this patch. The elevated context will be cleaned up in
last step. This is safe if we forget removing some hard-code permission.

Partially implements bp nova-api-policy-final-part

Change-Id: I1c26a1285c027ee51621c7b3b04c95daa5b835ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/49/150349/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Allow SAIO to answer is_local_device() better
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-15 05:40:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/6763e885dba6a911420e395ca4bd1d712ef34332', 'message': 'Allow SAIO to answer is_local_device() better

Common SAIO setups have multiple "servers" all on the same host with
different ports for the different "servers" (which happen to match the
IPs specified in the rings for the devices on each of those "servers").

This breaks down if you want to set up the SAIO to have one
object-server per disk.

However, you can configure the SAIO to have different localhost IP
addresses (e.g. 127.0.0.1, 127.0.0.2, etc.) in the ring and in the
servers' config files' bind_ip setting.

This new whataremyips() implementation combined with a little plumbing
allows is_local_device() to accurately answer, even on an SAIO.

In the default case (an unspecified bind_ip defaults to '0.0.0.0') as
well as an explict "bind to everything" like '0.0.0.0' (or for
completeness, the IPv6 equivalents
'0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000' and '::'), whataremyips()
behaves as it always has, returning all IP addresses for the server.

Change-Id: I7dfef9cc4a3c48145011d9d13d904e6b623de020
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-05-16 00:17:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/bf3c19e9c57f8133340cf8d2cde92d0a3082102c', 'message': 'Allow SAIO to answer is_local_device() better

Common SAIO setups have multiple "servers" all on the same host with
different ports for the different "servers" (which happen to match the
IPs specified in the rings for the devices on each of those "servers").

This breaks down if you want to set up the SAIO to have one
object-server per disk.

However, you can configure the SAIO to have different localhost IP
addresses (e.g. 127.0.0.1, 127.0.0.2, etc.) in the ring and in the
servers' config files' bind_ip setting.

This new whataremyips() implementation combined with a little plumbing
allows is_local_device() to accurately answer, even on an SAIO.

In the default case (an unspecified bind_ip defaults to '0.0.0.0') as
well as an explict "bind to everything" like '0.0.0.0' or '::',
whataremyips() behaves as it always has, returning all IP addresses for
the server.

commit_message:
Allow SAIO to answer is_local_device() better

Common SAIO setups have multiple "servers" all on the same host with
different ports for the different "servers" (which happen to match the
IPs specified in the rings for the devices on each of those "servers").

This breaks down if you want to set up the SAIO to have one
object-server per disk.

However, you can configure the SAIO to have different localhost IP
addresses (e.g. 127.0.0.1, 127.0.0.2, etc.) in the ring and in the
servers' config files' bind_ip setting.

This new whataremyips() implementation combined with a little plumbing
allows is_local_device() to accurately answer, even on an SAIO.

In the default case (an unspecified bind_ip defaults to '0.0.0.0') as
well as an explict "bind to everything" like '0.0.0.0' or '::',
whataremyips() behaves as it always has, returning all IP addresses for
the server.

Also updated probe tests to handle each "server" in the SAIO having a
unique IP address.

Change-Id: I7dfef9cc4a3c48145011d9d13d904e6b623de020
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/95/183395/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'bind_ip': self.ip, part_infos = list(self.reconstructor.collect_parts()) self.reconstructor.bind_ip = '0.0.0.0' # use whataremyips
deleted_lines: def _ips(): return ['127.0.0.1'] object_reconstructor.whataremyips = _ips with mock.patch('swift.obj.reconstructor.whataremyips', return_value=[self.ip]): part_infos = list(self.reconstructor.collect_parts())

commit_message:
Alter governance repo voting rules

Restrict Code-Review votes to -1..+1, but allow anyone to leave
them.  This will allow direct binary feedback from both TC and
non-TC members on a change (currently, feedback from non-TC members
requires leaving a comment).  Make Code-Review votes not required
for a change to merge.  This means they are purely advisory.

Add a TC-Vote label and allow TC members to vote -1..+1 on this
label.  This will allow the formal tallying of TC member votes.
It is also not required (by Gerrit) since the actual rules are
complicated and no one thinks implementing them in prolog is
a good idea.  So we will simply rely on the chair to tally the
votes properly and execute the workflow or abandon operations
as appropriate.

Change-Id: I510bf1195d8af5d5c466fb05630ad6f9ec11b3e1

commit_message:
Use oslo.log instead of oslo.incubator log module

oslo.log has graduated from oslo-incubator, magnum need use oslo.log
instead of oslo.incubator log module.

NOTE: openstack.common.log registers its options at import time, but
oslo.log needs to call register_options() explicitly.

Change-Id: I671bb020b628bd972813daf5936040b7f1c6bf7a
Closes-Bug: #1459736

commit_message:
Make ansible more verbose in gate-wrap

We have a case where ansible is taking over an hour to excute
what appears to be moving a file. This patch adds -vvv to the
ansible execution commands to see if we can get more information
about what is happening during that hour.

Job Reference:
https://jenkins01.openstack.org/job/check-tempest-dsvm-full/822/console

Change-Id: I22f2c3b97378996be21943ae9f01d14e07d38e83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/00/186900/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for service_get_by_compute_host

This patches remove the hard-code permission checks for db call
service_get_by_compute_host.

There are elevated contexts in the code used to call those methods which
aren't removed in this patch. The elevated context will be cleaned up in
last step. This is safe if we forget removing some hard-code permission.

Partially implements bp nova-api-policy-final-part

Change-Id: I06c90564e32a89761b752782d3fb74da9cc4d343
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/89/160089/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

As the docs point out(*), _exit should be used after a fork() to avoid
both processes flushing filehandles, calling destructors with side

commit_message:
Use os._exit after forking

As the docs point out(*), _exit should be used after a fork() to avoid
both processes flushing filehandles, calling destructors with side
effects, etc.  This change does just that.

(*) https://docs.python.org/2/library/os.html#os._exit

Change-Id: I68da6283c44ab8857baf217ac1443bd17988257d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/26/183426/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: os._exit(0)

commit_message:
Cleanup stale metadata processes on l3 agent sync

Currently l3 agent only cleans up stale namespaces.
The fix adds checking and deleting stale metadata processes
to NamespaceManager class responsible for clearing stale
namespaces

Change-Id: I2b081803e312589d3d8a7808d286a6c9827ef53f
Closes-Bug: #1455042

commit_message:
Switch from MySQL-python to PyMySQL

As discussed in the Liberty Design Summit "Moving apps to Python 3"
cross-project workshop, the way forward in the near future is to
switch to the pure-python PyMySQL library as a default.

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/liberty-cross-project-python3

Change-Id: Ib78f3fe7535ab1d86f1311d33152d88b2dbf9d1f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-apps refs/changes/82/184382/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - Return: format('mysql+pymysql://{0}@{1}:{2}', $username, $password, $host)

commit_message:
Map Mysql to isolated networks

This change adds parameters to specify which networks the MySQL
service will use. If the internal_api network exists the MySQL
service will bind to the IP address on that network, otherwise
the services will default to the IP on the Undercloud 'ctlplane'
network.

This patch also drop the old 'controller_host' variable from
the puppet controller template since it is no longer in use.

Change-Id: I4fba2c957f7db47e916bc269fb4bd32ccc99bd4c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/16/186416/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use heat inputs for network port settings

This patch updates the controller and compute roles
so that we use get_input in the software configuration
instead of calling get_attr/get_param there.

Change-Id: I1dc11987b4ea3c37775b14fbdddb75588499e9bb

commit_message:
Bump ddt to min version 0.7.0

Manila and manilaclient projects use lib "ddt" for testing. Both use feature
of this lib that appeared only starting with version 0.7.0 [1]
It worked till that moment because latest version was installed each time.
But it can cause errors in theory if current version 0.4.0 will be installed
indeed.

[1]: https://github.com/txels/ddt/commit/c55bbf5d

Change-Id: Iea6881a5efc7e3203747603727bec51bf4a4c0d8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/62/166162/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

oslo.vmware 0.13 now uses suds-jurko, instead of suds, which is
compatible with Python 3.

oslo.vmware 0.13 caused issues in nova, issue fixed in oslo.vmware

commit_message:
Bump oslo.vmware version to 0.13.1

oslo.vmware 0.13 now uses suds-jurko, instead of suds, which is
compatible with Python 3.

oslo.vmware 0.13 caused issues in nova, issue fixed in oslo.vmware
0.13.1.

This change prepares the work to drop the suds dependency.

Change-Id: I2fc039f6540b4a272f4e1abf3ea4e5240295e4c2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/74/186574/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add cli tests for --verify and friends

The tests that will change after the verify-always-true bug is fixed
are currently commented out.  The commented asserts show where we
want to go.

Also fixes --verify parser value

Change-Id: I891e3ead5fc3da3ed2ecba5d2befd9e910778655
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/30/179430/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_shell_args_no_options(self): def test_shell_args_ca_options(self): _shell = make_shell() # Default fake_execute(_shell, "list user") self.assertIsNone(_shell.options.verify) self.assertIsNone(_shell.options.insecure) self.assertEqual('', _shell.options.os_cacert) self.assertTrue(_shell.verify) # --verify fake_execute(_shell, "--verify list user") self.assertTrue(_shell.options.verify) self.assertIsNone(_shell.options.insecure) self.assertEqual('', _shell.options.os_cacert) self.assertTrue(_shell.verify) # --insecure fake_execute(_shell, "--insecure list user") self.assertIsNone(_shell.options.verify) self.assertTrue(_shell.options.insecure) self.assertEqual('', _shell.options.os_cacert) self.assertFalse(_shell.verify) # --os-cacert fake_execute(_shell, "--os-cacert foo list user") self.assertIsNone(_shell.options.verify) self.assertIsNone(_shell.options.insecure) self.assertEqual('foo', _shell.options.os_cacert) self.assertTrue(_shell.verify) # --os-cacert and --insecure # NOTE(dtroyer): This really is a bogus combination, we follow # the requests.Session convention and let --os-cacert # override --insecure fake_execute(_shell, "--os-cacert foo --insecure list user") self.assertIsNone(_shell.options.verify) self.assertTrue(_shell.options.insecure) self.assertEqual('foo', _shell.options.os_cacert) self.assertTrue(_shell.verify)

commit_message:
Update sqlalchemy-migrate to 0.9.6

Nova code change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/153123/ makes the db migrate
operation fail with db2. Need to update sqlalchemy-migrate to 0.9.6 to solve
this problem.

Change-Id: I3ccdc9117a07135cea2f7be1c516838a287b5ac9
Related-Bug: 1428477
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/21/181821/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

the channel to use and create a new channel for it. So it creates a new
channel after the each message send.

will be used at a time for one Connection object. So we can not close
the channel in reset().

commit_message:
Don't create a new channel in RabbitMQ Connection.reset()

Current implementation of RabbitMQ driver in in Connection.reset() change
the channel to use and create a new channel for it. This happens after the
each message send.

There no big need to create a new channel each time, so we can cancel all
consumer queues, instead of creating a channel in reset().

Test test_connection_reset_always_succeed() removed, because we are not
create channel on reset() anymore.

Co-Authored-By: Mehdi Abaakouk <sileht@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ie164840e6c055b01525b13aabdb8b9c7f5d1b98b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/72/182272/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.channel_pool = self.connection.ChannelPool(10) self.channel = self.channel_pool.acquire() execute_method, channel=self.channel or self.channel_pool.acquire(), if hasattr(self.channel, 'release'): self.channel.release() else: self.connection.maybe_close_channel(self.channel) self._set_current_channel(self.channel_pool.acquire()) except recoverable_errors:
deleted_lines: self.channel = None execute_method, channel=self.channel, self.connection.maybe_close_channel(self.channel) self._set_current_channel(self.connection.channel()) except recoverable_errors: self._set_current_channel(None)

commit_message:
Add #openstack-heat-translator to the list of irc channels

I have followed the access related instructions provided on
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/system-config/irc.html#access

Change-Id: I0d2de435c46a1d7be274291657ef532418b5dbe0

subject: Scheduler: Introduce a FilterRequestSpec class
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-23 11:05:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/4fd21a6774c14222a2aa812f8876238b0abed57e', 'message': 'Scheduler: Introduce a FilterRequestSpec object

As part of Scheduler refactoring, we are planning to move all the data
request_specs dict to NovaObjects. This effort is about solidifying the
external interfaces of the scheduler component, in hopes of moving it
out of the Nova project.

This patch can be seen as a small step in that direction, for the
purpose of using a more object like interface in the scheduler code
(mostly filters at this point).

As a basic example: We have a need to detect if the request sent to the
scheduler related to an instance attempts to change the flavor. We add
this functionality as a method on an object that wraps the request_spec
dictionary, that we can now use in filter code to make decisions.

With this we get to iterate over the objects API while punting the work
of actually changing the RPC API to use new objects to a later series,
while avoiding the need to add messy functionality as utility methods that
deal with request_spec dictionaries that are on their way out.

Change-Id: I4bdcfc1df9d0ed9b64c41213cd4e0613a1ab6c88
Partial-bug: #1370390
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-02 20:17:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/bc6c4f12d33e8b3bdca2dee1dfe156935624982d', 'message': 'Scheduler: Introduce a FilterRequestSpec object

commit_message:
Scheduler: Introduce a FilterRequestSpec class

As part of Scheduler refactoring, we are planning to move all the data
request_specs dict to NovaObjects. This effort is about solidifying the
external interfaces of the scheduler component, in hopes of moving it
out of the Nova project.

This patch can be seen as a small step in that direction, for the
purpose of using a more object like interface in the scheduler code
(mostly filters at this point).

As a basic example: We have a need to detect if the request sent to the
scheduler related to an instance attempts to change the flavor. We add
this functionality as a method on an object that wraps the request_spec
dictionary, that we can now use in filter code to make decisions.

With this we get to iterate over the objects API while punting the work
of actually changing the RPC API to use new objects to a later series,
while avoiding the need to add messy functionality as utility methods that
deal with request_spec dictionaries that are on their way out.

Change-Id: I4bdcfc1df9d0ed9b64c41213cd4e0613a1ab6c88
Partial-bug: #1370390

added_lines: from nova import contextfrom nova.tests.unit.objects import test_flavor as test_flavor_obj from nova.tests.unit import test_flavors instance_type = objects.Flavor(**test_flavor_obj.fake_flavor) class FilterRequestSpecTestCase(test.NoDBTestCase): def setUp(self): super(FilterRequestSpecTestCase, self).setUp() self.context = 'fake-context' self.flavor = objects.Flavor(**test_flavors.DEFAULT_FLAVORS[0]) self.instance = fake_instance.fake_instance_obj( self.context) self.instance.set_flavor(self.flavor) self.new_flavor = objects.Flavor(**test_flavors.DEFAULT_FLAVORS[1]) self.image = {'id': 42, 'properties': {'fake': 'prop'}} def test_init(self): request_spec = scheduler_utils.build_request_spec( self.context, self.image, [self.instance]) req_spec_obj = scheduler_utils.FilterRequestSpec(request_spec) # Test that the flavors are set as expected self.assertEqual(self.flavor.id, req_spec_obj.flavor.id) self.assertEqual(self.flavor.id, req_spec_obj.instance_flavor.id) # Test access to other stuff on request_spec dict self.assertEqual(req_spec_obj.image, request_spec['image']) self.assertEqual(req_spec_obj.instance_properties, request_spec['instance_properties']) self.assertEqual(req_spec_obj.num_instances, request_spec['num_instances']) self.assertFalse(req_spec_obj.new_flavor_requested()) self.assertRaises(AttributeError, getattr, req_spec_obj, 'foo') def test_new_flavor(self): request_spec = scheduler_utils.build_request_spec( self.context, self.image, [self.instance], instance_type=self.new_flavor) req_spec_obj = scheduler_utils.FilterRequestSpec(request_spec) self.assertTrue(req_spec_obj.new_flavor_requested())

commit_message:
Add an import whitelist helper factory

This patch adds a factory function for creating checks that allow
whitelisting imports in certain files.

The returned function can be registered as a pep8 check, and expects to
be passed the code to be used for the rule, a file to consider, and
whitelists of stdlib, 3rd party and project modules.

Unit tests that are part of this patch give an example of how this can
be used to create a function for fictional rules Z123 and Z223, that we
can
register using pep8.register_check or as an entry point for flake8.

Change-Id: I61979d555fb2d551cdc0a02d41af8fd3e03247af
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/hacking refs/changes/18/80018/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def whitelist_imports_in_file_factory(check_code, file_path, stdlib_whitelist, pip_whitelist, project_whitelist): msg = ("%(check_code)s: file %(filename)s does not allow " "'%(line)s' in imports.") format_dict = {'check_code': check_code, 'filename': file_path} def _whitelist_imports_check(logical_line, filename): if filename.startswith(file_path): import_line = logical_line.strip() normalized_line = import_normalize(import_line) if normalized_line.startswith('import '): _, module = normalized_line.split(' ') module = module.split(' as ')[0] package = module.partition('.')[0] import_type = _get_import_type(module) if import_type == 'stdlib': if module not in stdlib_whitelist: if package not in stdlib_whitelist: format_dict['line'] = import_line yield (0, msg % format_dict) if import_type == 'third-party': if module not in pip_whitelist: if package not in pip_whitelist: format_dict['line'] = import_line yield (0, msg % format_dict) if import_type == 'project': if module not in project_whitelist: format_dict['line'] = import_line yield (0, msg % format_dict) return _whitelist_imports_check

commit_message:
Match order of iptables arguments to iptables-save

The way we were forming our iptables rules was not matching
the output of iptables-save. This caused the logic that preserves
counters to miss many of the rules.

This patch corrects the order for the comments and the allowed address
pairs to match the output order of iptables-save.

Closes-Bug: #1456823
Change-Id: I34c2249d0865485578767865c82414e1d813d563
(cherry picked from commit 12889f70e1ae547598f4c663e9da5b9bb03e347e)

commit_message:
VMware: fill in instance metadata when resizing instances

Update instance metadata to the VMware resize spec. This is done by
updating the 'annotation' field. This enables an administrator
to search the VC according to values defined here.

Implemented blueprint vmware-driver-domain-metadata

Change-Id: I5794114e126a1bf0361e7035c40add8f7996468f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/36/144436/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_vm_resize_spec(client_factory, instance, extra_specs, metadata=None): if metadata: resize_spec.annotation = metadata

commit_message:
VMware: fill in instance metadata when launching instances

Add instance metadata to the VMware config spec. This is done by
updating the 'annotation' field. This enables an administrator
to search the VC according to values defined here.

Implemented blueprint vmware-driver-domain-metadata

Change-Id: Ia40fee366cab9ad99e276b0595fe0ad2972e54a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/28/141028/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: profile_spec=None, metadata=None): if metadata: config_spec.annotation = metadata

subject: Fix jah-1654
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-29 19:57:36.000000000', 'files': ['java/src/main/java/monasca/api/infrastructure/persistence/vertica/AlarmStateHistoryVerticaRepoImpl.java'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api/commit/809fc240ea449553d3173caa448b99918d08e841', 'message': 'Fix jah-1654

Read sub_alarms and metrics as JSON.

Change-Id: Ic659092a3c3885dceeb1e48c7520c32b0f52c68f
'}]
commit_message:
Fix jah-1654

Read sub_alarms and metrics as JSON.

Change-Id: Ic659092a3c3885dceeb1e48c7520c32b0f52c68f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api refs/changes/96/186896/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import monasca.common.model.alarm.AlarmState; import monasca.common.model.alarm.AlarmTransitionSubAlarm; import monasca.common.model.metric.MetricDefinition; import com.fasterxml.jackson.core.type.TypeReference; import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.ObjectMapper; import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.PropertyNamingStrategy;import org.joda.time.DateTimeZone;import java.io.IOException;import java.text.ParseException; import java.text.SimpleDateFormat; import java.util.ArrayList;import java.util.Date; private static final ObjectMapper objectMapper = new ObjectMapper(); static { objectMapper .setPropertyNamingStrategy(PropertyNamingStrategy.CAMEL_CASE_TO_LOWER_CASE_WITH_UNDERSCORES); } private static final TypeReference<List<MetricDefinition>> METRICS_TYPE = new TypeReference<List<MetricDefinition>>() {}; private static final TypeReference<List<AlarmTransitionSubAlarm>> SUB_ALARMS_TYPE = new TypeReference<List<AlarmTransitionSubAlarm>>() {}; private final SimpleDateFormat simpleDateFormat = new SimpleDateFormat("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.SSSX"); private final SimpleDateFormat oldSimpleDateFormat = new SimpleDateFormat("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ssX"); List<AlarmStateHistory> alarmStateHistoryList = new ArrayList<>(); for (Map<String, Object> row : verticaQuery.list()) { alarmStateHistoryList.add(getAlarmStateHistory(row)); } List<AlarmStateHistory> alarmStateHistoryList = new ArrayList<>(); for (Map<String, Object> row : verticaQuery.list()) { alarmStateHistoryList.add(getAlarmStateHistory(row)); } private AlarmStateHistory getAlarmStateHistory(Map<String, Object> row) { AlarmStateHistory alarmStateHistory = new AlarmStateHistory(); Date date; try { date = parseTimestamp(((Timestamp) row.get("timestamp")).toString() + "Z"); } catch (ParseException e) { logger.error("Failed to parse time", e); return null; } DateTime dateTime = new DateTime(date.getTime(), DateTimeZone.UTC); alarmStateHistory.setTimestamp(dateTime); alarmStateHistory.setAlarmId((String) row.get("alarm_id")); List<MetricDefinition> metricDefinitionList; try { metricDefinitionList = this.objectMapper.readValue((String) row.get("metrics"), METRICS_TYPE); } catch (IOException e) { logger.error("Failed to parse metrics", e); metricDefinitionList = new ArrayList<>(); } alarmStateHistory.setMetrics(metricDefinitionList); alarmStateHistory.setOldState(AlarmState.valueOf((String) row.get("old_state"))); alarmStateHistory.setNewState(AlarmState.valueOf((String) row.get("new_state"))); alarmStateHistory.setReason((String) row.get("reason")); alarmStateHistory.setReasonData((String) row.get("reason_data")); List<AlarmTransitionSubAlarm> subAlarmList; try { subAlarmList = this.objectMapper.readValue((String) row.get("sub_alarms"), SUB_ALARMS_TYPE); } catch (IOException e) { logger.error("Failed to parse sub-alarms", e); subAlarmList = new ArrayList<>(); } alarmStateHistory.setSubAlarms(subAlarmList); return alarmStateHistory; } private Date parseTimestamp(String timestampString) throws ParseException { try { return this.simpleDateFormat.parse(timestampString); } catch (ParseException pe) { // This extra part is here just to handle dates in the old format of only // having seconds. This should be removed in a month or so return this.oldSimpleDateFormat.parse(timestampString); } }
deleted_lines: import monasca.common.persistence.BeanMapper; List<AlarmStateHistory> alarmStateHistoryList; alarmStateHistoryList = verticaQuery.map(new BeanMapper<>(AlarmStateHistory.class)).list(); List<AlarmStateHistory> alarmStateHistoryList; alarmStateHistoryList = verticaQuery.map(new BeanMapper<>(AlarmStateHistory.class)).list();

commit_message:
Add debug-user element

This adds an element that can be used to set up a separate user for
in the appliance for debugging purposes.

Change-Id: I46777b785f8575acdc50ee19c059b08b89bfed98
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack-attic/akanda-appliance-builder refs/changes/96/185196/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash DIB_AKANDA_APPLIANCE_DEBUG_USER=${DIB_AKANDA_APPLIANCE_DEBUG_USER:-akanda-debug} DIB_AKANDA_APPLIANCE_DEBUG_PASSWORD=${DIB_AKANDA_APPLIANCE_DEBUG_PASSWORD:-akanda} set -eu set -o xtrace useradd -m $DIB_AKANDA_APPLIANCE_DEBUG_USER -s /bin/bash passwd $DIB_AKANDA_APPLIANCE_DEBUG_USER <<EOF $DIB_AKANDA_APPLIANCE_DEBUG_PASSWORD $DIB_AKANDA_APPLIANCE_DEBUG_PASSWORD EOF cat > /etc/sudoers.d/akanda-debug-user <<eof $DIB_AKANDA_APPLIANCE_DEBUG_USER ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD:ALL eof chmod 0440 /etc/sudoers.d/akanda-debug-user visudo -c

commit_message:
Fix proxy delete error

I discovered with the functional tests that the delete proxy
was broken.  It should pass ignore_missing as a keyword argument
rather than positional.

Change-Id: I9281f5477a42428b301b2af019bb5ccc2684100d

on passing in env variables

commit_message:
Add Nova as Pacemaker resource

Constraints based on vncproxy are commented due to it not starting
with websockify < 0.6, see [1]

1. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-October/048535.html

Co-Authored-By: Jiri Stransky <jistr@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ie51014bf563920d2e75c5e38942bc42ddc2a3939

commit_message:
Add Backend grading, and associated docs page

This adds a parameter to the backend class the defines its grade.
It can be overridden in the support-matrix.ini file it needed.

Change-Id: Icbcb3d88242c6d2de2c361722ddea85d4b585fca

commit_message:
Remove the no-parallel setting from pretty_tox.sh

pretty_tox.sh was setting --no-parallel, so even if you
wanted to be dangerous and live on the edge you couldn't.

This patch removest that limiter and let's you either:
 a. Run as many processes as you have nproc
 b. Specify how many processes you want by using
    "tox -- --concurrency=<n>"

Note that much past 6, things get a bit unstable.  Your
mileage may vary.  Gate appears to use 8, ran a sequence
of 10 iterations locally succesfully after modifying the
gluster tests. May be other gotchas out there though.

Change-Id: I593b8086f19c37a5abc55a23f92253706e100daf
Closes-Bug: #1459852
Parital-Bug: #1459854

commit_message:
Drop simplejson which was needed for Python 2.6

In 2.6 and earlier, the JSON module wasn't loaded as a C module, so it
was helpful to use simplejson if it was available. Since Python 2.6
support has been dropped in Kilo, remove the logic around simplejson.

Change-Id: I32f06b730d575ccf4770007aedf5e6902284d939

commit_message:
OVS_LIB support API for setting fail mode 'standalone'

The current API only support setting a bridge fail mode
to secure, this patch allow the user to set it to 'standalone'
as well

Change-Id: If7e6532dc7f8527c35834a37144ea4386fe1b861
Closes-Bug: #1458924

commit_message:
Remove appliance's hard-coded password in favor of ssh pub key

This removes the hard-coded password from the appliance VM's user-data
and replaces it with a SSH public key, which is read from a file whos
path is configured in rug.ini.

It also disables password logins for the user.  Another patch to
akanda-appliance-builder will allow developers to include a specified
debug user to allow debugging in dev environments.

Change-Id: I7db92bc7fd3743d89d73ab2a0b8da14685c30c69
(cherry picked from commit a06dbe7ab3d579c0c4cb84642ed1708d1442dc0b)

commit_message:
Fixing cue integration test gate

- Updated requirement.txt with accept libraries and versions
- Have DIB repo cloned by the devstack-vm gate
- Modify cluster test to test create, get, list and delete in one test
- Temporary disabled install of cue-dashboard until cloning issue
  is fixed

Change-Id: Ie5ffaf169d3915c4bd73d61ab05bfa8ac3f7f36b

subject: Remove pretty_tox and use ostestr
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-29 18:07:38.000000000', 'files': ['requirements.txt', 'tox.ini', 'tools/pretty_tox.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/b46a895a11e7a4656991e38f591a7f750e966510', 'message': 'Remove pretty_tox and use ostestr

This patch dumps pretty_tox.sh and gets Cinder on board
with using ostestr.  We're setting a concurrency value
of 6 (instances in the gate are 6 VCPU's), and things
seem to be stable at this value.

For folks running on 'smaller' system, it's still possible
to run in parallell > ncpu's but if there are problems you
can still specify concurrency in your tox argument.  Tox will
take the last occurence of the conncurrency argument; so for
example if you specify "tox -epy27 -- --concurrency=4" the
interpretted value for concurrency in the run will be 4.

Change-Id: I78c573367ffa1b2859c49e3ad6fcb4e586210f02
'}]
commit_message:
Remove pretty_tox and use ostestr

This patch dumps pretty_tox.sh and gets Cinder on board
with using ostestr.  We're setting a concurrency value
of 6 (instances in the gate are 6 VCPU's), and things
seem to be stable at this value.

For folks running on 'smaller' system, it's still possible
to run in parallell > ncpu's but if there are problems you
can still specify concurrency in your tox argument.  Tox will
take the last occurence of the conncurrency argument; so for
example if you specify "tox -epy27 -- --concurrency=4" the
interpretted value for concurrency in the run will be 4.

Change-Id: I78c573367ffa1b2859c49e3ad6fcb4e586210f02
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/59/186859/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

the solution is not to save in the async thread. The main thread
and the async thread share a reference to the same object and the

to the DB. The change to 'network_allocated' would be written to
the DB but not updated on the instance object. When the network

to the DB. After the reschedule, the instance would still have
'network_allocated' set to True, and skip allocating a network.
The node would go active with no network.

Since this is happening in the _allocate_network_async greenthread,
the solution is not to save in the async thread. The main thread
and the async thread share a reference to the same object and the
main thread waits for the async thread to finish before the final
save, so saving is unnecessary. I added comments on the
instance.save() calls that were part of the race so they don't get

commit_message:
Reschedules sometimes do not allocate networks

Changes to instance.system_metadata weren't properly being saved
to the DB. The change to 'network_allocated' would be written to
the DB but not updated on the instance object. When the network
was cleaned up before a reschedule, the object would not notice
network_allocated' getting set to False, and not write the change
to the DB. After the reschedule, the instance would still have
'network_allocated' set to True, and skip allocating a network.
The node would go active with no network.

Since this is happening in the _allocate_network_async greenthread,
the solution is not to save in the async thread. The main thread
and the async thread share a reference to the same object and the
main thread waits for the async thread to finish before the final
save, so saving is unnecessary. I added comments on the
instance.save() calls that were part of the race so they don't get
removed or changed and reintroduce this bug.

Also, update the relevant test from mox to mock.

Change-Id: I937ec020b46703392bd603008d03af0f422bc0d1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/70/177470/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: instance.system_metadata['network_allocated'] = 'True' instance.save()
deleted_lines: sys_meta = instance.system_metadata sys_meta['network_allocated'] = 'True' self._instance_update(context, instance.uuid, system_metadata=sys_meta)

commit_message:
Created working directory for Cloud Admin Guide RST conversion

1. Added config files and edited scripts to build the RST Cloud Admin Guide

subject: Revert "Merge "Bootstrap variable overrides should only be default values""
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-28 08:48:57.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_dashboard/static/dashboard/scss/_variables.scss'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/88d8f1f4b2d508e22ee5956e017a2c6ae5126ac8', 'message': 'Revert "Merge "Bootstrap variable overrides should only be default values""

This reverts commit 1fefd0f4259d670cea4075a7a3e52caeaab7ea9b, reversing
changes made to 74e6da9f4314a96b6d714c966699435316b4c075.

This patch incorrectly layers defaults in SCSS, which doesn't work. A
default does not override another default, so adding !default to our
overrides has caused them not to work.

Closes-Bug: 1459573

commit_message:
Revert "Merge "Bootstrap variable overrides should only be default values""

This reverts commit 1fefd0f4259d670cea4075a7a3e52caeaab7ea9b, reversing
changes made to 74e6da9f4314a96b6d714c966699435316b4c075.

This patch incorrectly layers defaults in SCSS, which doesn't work. A
default does not override another default, so adding !default to our
overrides has caused them not to work.

Change-Id: I9f9c98262a428d84efe7887f76ff9e1af451c29b
Closes-Bug: 1459573
